{{Infobox building | name = Duke University Marine Laboratory | alternate_names = Duke Marine Lab | image = File:Pilkey Lab, Duke University Marine Laboratory, Beaufort, NC.jpg | caption = Pilkey laboratory at the Duke Marine Lab | location = | location_town = Piver's Island (Private) | location_country = United States of America | opened_date = 1938 | owner = [[Duke University]] }}The '''Duke University Marine Laboratory''' (commonly referred to as the "Duke Marine Lab") is a research facility and campus of [[Duke University]] on Piver's Island, a private island,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Norman|first=Christensen|date=Fall 2015|title=Nicholas School of the Environment at Duke University|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/sites/default/files/f15.pdf|journal=DukEnvironment|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> near [[Beaufort, North Carolina|Beaufort]] and the [[Outer Banks]], [[North Carolina]] specializing in studying [[marine biology]]. It is part of the [[Nicholas School of the Environment]]'s Division of Marine Science and Conservation.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/marinelab/about/mission-statement-and-history|title=Mission Statement & History {{!}} Nicholas School|website=nicholas.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref>
The current official goal of the Marine Laboratory is to study marine [[environmental systems]] and [[Conservation biology|conservation]] utilizing the resources of the facility's proximity to the ocean.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://twitter.com/DukeMarineLab|title=Description of Duke Marine Lab (@DukeMarineLab) {{!}} Twitter|last=|first=|date=|website=twitter.com|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> It is a member of the National Association of Marine Laboratories<ref name=":0" /> and the Marine Sciences Education Consortium.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://www.marquette.edu/biology/undergrad-dukeuniversity.shtml|title=Duke University > Biological Sciences > Marquette University|website=www.marquette.edu|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref>
== History == The main campus of Duke University is not in close proximity to the ocean, but with the Marine Laboratory campus, the University is able to conduct hands-own oceanographic studies.
The site for the laboratory was selected in the early 1930s, with the first building completed by 1938.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://today.duke.edu/2013/10/archivesmarinelab|title=From the Archives: Marine Lab 'Then and Now'|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en}}</ref> The original intention of the facility was to be a summer training facility and research facility for the university.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://library.duke.edu/rubenstein/findingaids/uansoe/|title=Guide to the Nicholas School of the Environment Records, 1916-ongoing|website=David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref>
By 1963, the facility had reached national recognition for its resources. At the time 75% of students and 40% of researchers came from other universities than Duke.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bookhout|first=C.G.|date=1963|title=DUKE UNIVERSITY MARINE LABORATORY|url=https://academic.oup.com/icb/article-pdf/3/3/270/5936741/3-3-270.pdf|journal=Marine Laboratories|volume=|pages=270-272|via=OUP}}</ref>
[[Sylvia Earle]], a renowned oceanographer<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsweek.com/last-dive-funding-human-expeditions-ocean-may-have-run-aground-63201|title=The Last Dive?|date=2013-01-14|work=Newsweek|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en}}</ref> and pioneer of [[Jacques Cousteau]]'s AquaLung [[Scuba diving|Scuba]] device, received her M.S. and Ph.D. from [[Duke University|Duke]] in 1956 and 1966, and has a connection to the Marine Laboratory.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://gradschool.duke.edu/about/news/sylvia-earle-face-marine-biology-receives-distinguished-alumni-award|title=Sylvia Earle, “Face of Marine Biology,” Receives Distinguished Alumni Award {{!}} Duke Graduate School|website=gradschool.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref>
In 1990, the laboratory assumed much of the research of [[Fairleigh Dickinson University]]'s West Indies Laboratory for Underwater Research in [[Saint Croix|St. Croix]], [[Virgin Islands]] after [[Hurricane Hugo]] damaged the St. Croix facility.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/05/02/us/education-year-of-classes-canceled-at-marine-lab.html|title=EDUCATION; Year of Classes Canceled at Marine Lab|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/20/us/education-fairleigh-dickinson-closing-laboratory-on-virgin-islands.html|title=EDUCATION; Fairleigh Dickinson Closing Laboratory On Virgin Islands|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en}}</ref>
[[Cindy Lee Van Dover]] was named the first female-director of the center in 2007. She has initially worked at the laboratory in the 1970s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/16/science/16conv.html|title=Deep in the Sea, Imagining the Cradle of Life on Earth|last=Dreifus|first=Claudia|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en}}</ref>
On June 5, 2017, the Marine Laboratory participated in a green-illumination protest with other buildings at [[Duke University|Duke]] in support of the [[Paris Agreement|Paris Climate Accords]] along with similar actions at [[Harvard University|Harvard]], [[Stanford University|Stanford]], [[Yale University|Yale]], [[Columbia University|Columbia]], and [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology|MIT]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.newsobserver.com/news/local/education/article154448114.html|title=Duke’s environment school joins list of buildings being lit green|work=newsobserver|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en}}</ref>
== Facilities and Ships ==
Since its inception in 1938, the campus has expanded significantly to include [[Wet laboratory|wet]] and [[dry lab]]oratories<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/sites/default/files/dumlmap.pdf|title=Duke Marine Lab Campus Map|last=|first=|date=|website=Duke University|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> as well as a fleet of research ships.
=== Land-based Facilities ===
==== Research Facilities ==== * "Lab 1," in continuous operation since 1938, contains running sea-water tables<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/marinelab/about/facilities|title=Facilities {{!}} Nicholas School|website=nicholas.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> * Marguerite Kent Repass Ocean Conservation Center "Green Marine Lab"<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/marinelab/about/facilities/marguerite-kent-repass-ocean-conservation-center|title=Marguerite Kent Repass Ocean Conservation Center {{!}} Nicholas School|website=nicholas.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> * Marine Conservation Molecular Facility (MCMF)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/marinelab/about/facilities/marine-conservation-molecular-facility-mcmf|title=Marine Conservation Molecular Facility (MCMF) {{!}} Nicholas School|website=nicholas.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> * Orrin Pilkey Laboratory<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/marinelab/about/facilities/orrin-pilkey-laboratory|title=Orrin Pilkey Laboratory {{!}} Nicholas School|website=nicholas.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> * Bookhout Research Laboratory<ref name=":4" /> * Pearse Memorial Library and associated computer equipment<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://library.duke.edu/marine/facilities|title=Facilities at the Marine Lab Library|last=janil.miller|date=2013-08-20|website=library.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref>
==== Support Facilities ==== * Dormitory Capacity for 142 Persons (92 Students)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/marinelab/visiting/facilities-rental-information|title=Facilities Rental Information {{!}} Nicholas School|website=nicholas.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> * Dining Facilities * Boathouse Lounge<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://sites.nicholas.duke.edu/dumlenrollment/recreation/|title=Recreation – Duke Marine Lab Enrollment|website=sites.nicholas.duke.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> * Student Center<ref name=":1" />
=== Ocean Vessels (Former and Current) === * The Eastward<ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/dukeyearlook/5576986401/in/album-72157626454782080/|title="The Eastward," undated|work=Flickr|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en-us}}</ref> * Cape Hatteras<ref name=":3" /> * R/V Richard Barber<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/marinelab/about/boats|title=Boats {{!}} Nicholas School|website=nicholas.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> * R/V Kirby-Smith<ref name=":5" /> * Various Skiffs<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/marinelab/visiting|title=Visiting the Duke Marine Lab {{!}} Nicholas School|website=nicholas.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> * Unnamed Future Vessel (2018). This ship will be funded by an $11 million gift from Duke University Trustee and alumnus [[Jeffrey W. Ubben|Jef]]<nowiki/>[[Jeffrey W. Ubben|f Ubben]] and built in partnership with the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)]]. It increases the scope of the research possible at the facility by expanding the duration and capacity of sea voyages.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wnct.com/news/duke-marine-lab-receives-11-million-gift-for-research-vessel_20180319092932536/1057916379|title=Duke Marine Lab receives $11 million gift for research vessel|last=Tew|first=Elizabeth|date=2017-08-16|work=WNCT|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.heraldsun.com/news/local/counties/durham-county/article192364329.html|title=They work to save the world’s elephants. Now a grant makes Duke a partner|work=heraldsun|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en}}</ref>
== Partnerships == [[Duke University]] shares Piver's Island with the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA)]], whichhas a 60,000 square foot marine laboratory.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://coastalscience.noaa.gov/about/facilities/|title=Facilities - NCCOS Coastal Science Website|work=NCCOS Coastal Science Website|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en-US}}</ref> The current director of the National Laboratory is also an alum of Duke University.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://sites.nicholas.duke.edu/odar/marine-lab-alum-named-director-of-noaa-lab-next-door/|title=Marine Lab Alum Named Director Of NOAA Lab Next Door – Office of Development and Alumni Relations|website=sites.nicholas.duke.edu|language=en-US|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> Duke has partnerships with other universities for marine research, such as [[Wittenberg University]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.wittenberg.edu/academics/marinescience/student-opportunities|title=Marine Science Student Opportunities {{!}} Wittenberg University|website=www.wittenberg.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> [[Franklin & Marshall College|Franklin and Marshall College]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:YE3Z6E-NiJAJ:https://offcampus.fandm.edu/index.cfm?FuseAction=Programs.ViewProgram&Program_ID=25910+&cd=9&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=us|title=Duke University Marine Lab|website=International & Off-Campus Study|language=en-us|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> and [[Marquette University]],<ref name=":2" /> for use of the Marine Laboratory for students.
== Research and Media Coverage == The research originating from the laboratory has often been published in scientific journals, such as ''Policy Studies Journal'',<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Siddiki|first=Saba|last2=Weible|first2=Christopher M.|last3=Basurto|first3=Xavier|last4=Calanni|first4=John|date=2011-02-15|title=Dissecting Policy Designs: An Application of the Institutional Grammar Tool|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1541-0072.2010.00397.x|journal=Policy Studies Journal|language=en|volume=39|issue=1|pages=79–103|doi=10.1111/j.1541-0072.2010.00397.x|issn=0190-292X|via=}}</ref> ''Ecology Letters'',<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Forward Jr|first=|last2=De Vries|last3=Tankersley|last4=Rittschof|last5=Hettler|last6=Burke|last7=Welch|last8=Hoss|date=2004-02-24|title=Behaviour and sensory physiology of Atlantic menhaden larvae, Brevoortia tyrannus, during horizontal transport|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1046/j.1365-2419.1999.00023.x|journal=Fisheries Oceanography|language=en|volume=8|issue=s2|pages=37–56|doi=10.1046/j.1365-2419.1999.00023.x|issn=1054-6006|via=}}</ref> ''Marine Turtle'',<ref>Mrosovsky, Nicholas et all. ''[http://pordlabs.ucsd.edu/jsprintall/pub_dir/MTN130.pdf Marine Turtle Newsletter].'' Issue 130, November 2011. ''ucsd.edu''. Retrieved 2018-07-28.</ref> and ''Conservation Biology.''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=COX|first=T. M.|last2=LEWISON|first2=R. L.|last3=ŽYDELIS|first3=R.|last4=CROWDER|first4=L. B.|last5=SAFINA|first5=C.|last6=READ|first6=A. J.|date=2007-10-19|title=Comparing Effectiveness of Experimental and Implemented Bycatch Reduction Measures: the Ideal and the Real|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1523-1739.2007.00772.x|journal=Conservation Biology|language=en|volume=21|issue=5|pages=1155–1164|doi=10.1111/j.1523-1739.2007.00772.x|issn=0888-8892|via=}}</ref>
Recently, the laboratory's research about the effect of plastic on sea coral has gained national media coverage.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/speaking-of-science/wp/2017/10/30/corals-eat-plastic-because-weve-made-it-tasty-study-suggests/|title=Corals eat plastic because we've made it tasty, study suggests|website=Washington Post|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> Other notable research includes the interaction of light pollution and marine life<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.witn.com/content/news/Duke-Marine-Lab-student-researches-light-pollution-on-sea-turtles-and-hatchlings-477694203.html|title=Duke Marine Lab student researches light pollution on sea turtles and hatchlings|last=WITN|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en}}</ref> and studies of whale migration patterns.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/48407880/ns/technology_and_science-science/t/humpback-whales-linger-antarctica/|title=Humpback whales linger in Antarctica|date=2012-07-31|work=msnbc.com|access-date=2018-07-28|language=en}}</ref>
In 2017, the Marine Laboratory was featured in [[television series]] [[Xploration Station]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://nicholas.duke.edu/about/news/eos-undergrad-appear-tv-show-philippe-cousteau|title=EOS Undergrad to Appear on TV Show with Philippe Cousteau {{!}} Nicholas School|website=nicholas.duke.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-07-28}}</ref> with [[Philippe Cousteau Jr.]], the grandson of oceanographer [[Jacques Cousteau]].
== See also == * [[Stanford University]]'s [[Hopkins Marine Station]] * [[University of Hawaii]]'s [[Hawaiʻi Institute of Marine Biology|Institute of Marine Biology (HIMB)]] * [[University of New England (United States)|University of New England]]'s Marine Biology Program * [[University of New Hampshire]]'s Marine Biology Program * [[University of Tampa]]'s Marine Biology Program

'''Half maximal effective concentration''' ('''EC<sub>50</sub>''') refers to the concentration of a drug, antibody or toxicant which induces a response halfway between the baseline and maximum after a specified exposure time.<ref>[http://www.graphpad.com/curvefit/introduction89.htm Introducing dose response curves] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070219185355/http://www.graphpad.com/curvefit/introduction89.htm |date=2007-02-19 }}, Graphpad Software</ref> It is commonly used as a measure of a drug's potency. EC<sub>50</sub> is expressed in [[Molar concentration|molar units]] (M), where 1 M is equivalent to 1 [[Mole (unit)|mol]]/[[Liter|L]].
The EC<sub>50</sub> of a ''graded'' [[dose response curve]] therefore represents the concentration of a compound where 50% of its maximal effect is observed.<ref>[http://www.biochem.northwestern.edu/holmgren/Glossary/Definitions/Def-E/EC50.html EC50 definition]</ref> The EC<sub>50</sub> of a ''quantal'' dose response curve represents the concentration of a compound where 50% of the population exhibit a response,<ref>[http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/190116.htm definition of EC<sub>50</sub> for quantal dose response curve]</ref> after a specified exposure duration.
It is also related to [[IC50|IC<sub>50</sub>]] which is a measure of a compound's inhibition (50% inhibition). For competition binding assays and functional antagonist assays [[IC50|IC<sub>50</sub>]] is the most common summary measure of the dose-response curve. For agonist/stimulator assays the most common summary measure is the EC<sub>50</sub>.<ref>[http://www.ncgc.nih.gov/guidance/section3.html Assay Operations for SAR Support] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061129102848/http://www.ncgc.nih.gov/guidance/section3.html |date=2006-11-29 }} NIH Chemical Genomics Center</ref> The half maximal effective concentration is sometimes also expressed as <!-- pEC50 redirects here - the following term is bolded per MOS:BOLD -->'''pEC<sub>50</sub>''' instead of EC<sub>50</sub>, where: :<math chem>\ce{pEC50} = -\log_{10} (\ce{EC50}) </math>
A small change in [[ligand]] concentration typically results in rapid changes in response in the biological system, following a [[Sigmoid function|sigmoid]]al function. The [[inflection point]] at which the increase in response with increasing ligand concentration begins to slow is the EC<sub>50</sub>, which can be mathematically determined by derivation of the best-fit line. While relying on a graph for estimation is more convenient, this typical method yields less accurate results and less precise.<ref>[http://www.ncgc.nih.gov/guidance/section3.html Assay Operations for SAR Support] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061129102848/http://www.ncgc.nih.gov/guidance/section3.html |date=2006-11-29 }} NIH Chemical Genomics Center</ref>
== Equation == Many different equations can be used to derive an EC<sub>50</sub>. One possible function is:
:<math chem>Y = (\ce{Bottom}) + \frac\ce{(Top) - (Bottom)}{1 + \left(\frac\ce{X}\ce{EC50}\right)^{-(\text{Hill coefficient})} }</math>
where Y is the observed value, Bottom is the lowest observed value, Top is the highest observed value, and the [[Hill coefficient]] gives the largest absolute value of the slope of the curve.<ref>[http://www.sigmaplot.com/products/sigmaplot/Standard_Curves_Analysis.pdf EC50 equation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120417121807/http://www.sigmaplot.com/products/sigmaplot/Standard_Curves_Analysis.pdf |date=2012-04-17 }} - see page 5</ref>
== Limitations ==
The effects of a stressor or drug generally depend on the exposure time. Therefore, the EC<sub>50</sub> (and similar statistics) will be a function of exposure time. The exact shape of this time function will depend upon the stressor (e.g., the specific toxicant), its mechanism of action, the organism exposed, etc. This time dependency hampers the comparison of [[Potency (pharmacology)|potency]] or [[toxicity]] between compounds and between different organisms.
== See also == * [[Measures of pollutant concentration]] * [[Dose-response relationship]] * [[Certain safety factor]] * [[IC50|IC<sub>50</sub>]] (half maximal inhibitory concentration) * [[LD50|LD<sub>50</sub>]] (median lethal dose) * [[Therapeutic index]]

{{see also|engineering education}} {{cleanup|reason=There may be other reasons, but there is no information under the "Industry" heading, for starters.|date=December 2013}}
'''Engineering education research (EER)''' is the field of inquiry that creates knowledge which aims to define, inform, and improve the education of engineers. It achieves this through research on topics such as: epistemology, policy, assessment, pedagogy, diversity, amongst others, as they pertain to engineering.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nazempour |first1=Arshan |title=Assessments of Ultra-Low-Cost Venturi Nozzle in Undergraduate Engineering Classes |journal=American Society For Engineering Education |date=2015 |url=https://www.asee.org/public/conferences/56/papers/12706/view |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304052137/https://www.asee.org/public/conferences/56/papers/12706/view |archivedate=2016-03-04 |df= }}</ref>
==History and background==
Engineering education research gained visibility during the 1980s, although the formal education of engineers in the [[United States]] traces back to as early as 1802, with the establishment of the United States Military Academy at West Point for the purpose of training the U.S. Army's corps of engineers.<ref>Noble, D. F. (1979). America by design: Science, technology, and the rise of corporate capitalism.</ref><ref>Reynolds, Terry S. (1992). "The Education of Engineers in America Before the Morrill Act of 1862," History of Education Quarterly, 32 (Winter): 459-82.</ref> The Rensselaer School (now Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute) was founded in 1824 and conferred degrees in civil engineering upon four students in 1835.<ref>Society for the Promotion of Engineering Education. (1930). "Report of the Investigation of Engineering Education 1923-1929." Pittsburgh, PA.</ref>
Spurred by concerns of national competitiveness and the insufficient number of graduating engineers<ref>A Nation at Risk (1983)</ref> the Neal Report called for research to improve teaching and learning in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics) fields.<ref>Neal Report (1986)</ref>
Similar to other disciplines, the 1990s brought a focus on the scholarship of teaching as demonstrated by the 1995 NRC Report,<ref>National Research Council Board on Engineering Education. 1995. Engineering education: Designing an adaptive system. Washington, DC: National Academies Press.</ref> "Engineering education: Designing an adaptive system", influenced by Ernst Boyer.<ref>Boyer, E.L. 1990. Scholarship reconsidered: Priorities of the professoriate. Princeton, NJ: Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching National Academies Press.</ref> This focus was primarily motivated by the need to improve the quality of engineers produced by universities in the US. Additionally, 1993 marked the relaunch of the ''[[Journal of Engineering Education]]'', which served as a clearinghouse for scholarly research.<ref name="Jesiek_etal_2009">{{cite journal |author=Brent K. Jesiek |author2=Lynita K. Newswander |author3=Maura Borrego |last-author-amp=yes |year=2009 |title=Engineering education research: discipline, community, or field? |journal=[[Journal of Engineering Education]] |volume=98 |issue=1 |pages=39–52 |doi=10.1002/j.2168-9830.2009.tb01004.x}}</ref>
As concerns regarding globalization and the need for innovation increased during the late 1990s and 2000s, engineering education research was influenced by calls of reform to produce the quantity and diversity of engineers needed to address global problems.<ref name="Jesiek_etal_2009"/>
Continuing the development of the field, centers for engineering education research emerged in the early 2000s. The NAE formed a Committee on Engineering Education (CEE) in 1999, NAE’s Center for the Advancement of Scholarship on Engineering Education (CASEE) was established in 2002 and the Center for the Advancement of Engineering in 2003.<ref name="Jesiek_etal_2009"/>
During the mid-2000s, dedicated funding, specialized publications, centers for research, academic preparation and conferences which connected the distributed community supplied the infrastructure necessary for the burgeoning field of research.<ref name="Jesiek_etal_2009"/>

== Core research areas ==
The 2006 Report of the Steering Committee of the National Engineering Education Research Colloquies outlined the 5 key topic areas of engineering education research as follows:<ref>Colloquies. (2006). The Research Agenda for the New Discipline of Engineering Education. ''[[Journal of Engineering Education]]'' (October), 259-261.</ref>
# Engineering Epistemologies: Research on what constitutes engineering thinking and knowledge within [[social context]]s now and into the future # Engineering Learning Mechanisms: Research on engineering learners’ developing knowledge and competencies in context. # Engineering Learning Systems: Research on the [[instructional culture]], [[institutional infrastructure]], and [[epistemology]] of engineering educators. # Engineering Diversity and Inclusiveness: Research on how diverse human talents contribute solutions to the social and global challenges and relevance of our [the engineering] profession. # Engineering Assessment: Research on, and the development of, assessment methods, instruments, and metrics to inform [[engineering education]] practice and learning.
== Other research areas ==
=== Globalization === According to Borrego and Bernhard,<ref name="Borrego_Bernhard">Borrego, M., & Bernhard, J. (2011) "The emergence of engineering education research as an internationally connected field of inquiry." ''[[Journal of Engineering Education]]''. 100 (1): 14–47.</ref> international collaborations are developing in an effort to create global competencies in engineering students. Engineering global competency is the possession of "the knowledge, ability, and predisposition to work effectively with people who define and solve problems differently than they do." <ref>Downey et al., "The Globally Competent Engineer: Working Effectively with People Who Define Problems Differently," ''[[Journal of Engineering Education]]'', 2006.</ref> Educational programs that emphasize global engineering competencies research the development and assessment of global competency within the engineering practice.<ref>https://engineering.purdue.edu/GEP</ref><ref>https://globalhub.org/resources/4427/download/GE3_April_2011_bkj_final.pdf</ref>
Examples of programs in global engineering competency include: *The Global Engineering Program at Purdue University *[[Erasmus mundus]] (student centric global program)<ref>http://ec.europa.eu/education/external-relation-programmes/doc72_en.htm</ref>
R&D departments in transnational companies also contribute to international educational research.
===Global engineering cultures===
In 2008, a project titled "The Engineering Cultures Multimedia Project" was approved by the NSF. It was done by combine effort of "Virginia Tech and Colorado School of Mines to produce CD-based modules exploring how what counts as an engineer and engineering knowledge varies from country to country". https://globalhub.org/topics/AboutEngineeringCultures The main goal of this project was "To develop, disseminate, and assess learning experiences that will help students to identify, understand, and value perspectives other than their own."<ref>https://globalhub.org/topics/EngineeringCultures</ref>
=== Pre-college engineering education ===
Studies indicate that engineers will be better prepared for rigorous study in the engineering sciences if exposed to engineering concepts in the years prior to university study. The following resources have been listed to provide primary- and secondary-level educators with information and online programs that will aide them in bringing engineering material to their classrooms.
== Methodology == “Rigorous” research in engineering education is defined as adherence to the [[United States National Research Council|National Research Council]]’s six guiding principles for [[scientific inquiry]].<ref>Borrego, M. (2007). "Conceptual difficulties experienced by trained engineers learning educational research methods." ''[[Journal of Engineering Education]]''. 96(2): 91.</ref> The six guiding principles for scientific inquiry are:<ref>Shavelson, R., and L. Towne, Scientific Research in Education, Washington, D.C.: National Academies Press, 2002. Scientific Research in Education, Washington, D.C.: National Academies Press, 2002.</ref>
# Pose significant questions that can be investigated empirically. # Link research to relevant theory. # Use methods that permit direct investigation of the question. # Provide explicit, coherent chain of reasoning. # Replicate and generalize across studies. # Disclose research to encourage professional scrutiny and critique.
== Connection to practice ==
Engineering education research is conducted based on the demands and patterns of engineering in industry, policy, and education. Globally, emphasis of research focuses on educational application. Research into industry and practice have yet to gain greater attention.<ref name="Jesiek_etal_2010">Jesiek, B. K., Borrego, M., & Beddoes, K. (2010) "Advancing global capacity for engineering education research (AGCEER): relating research to practice, policy, and industry." ''[[Journal of Engineering Education]]''. 99 (2): 107-119.</ref>
=== Industry ===
=== Policy ===
In the [[United States]], there has been a greater push for development of formal policy for educating engineers. In 1918, the [http://www.google.com/search?sourceid=navclient&ie=UTF-8&rlz=1T4GGLL_enUS374US374&q=Mann%2c+C.+%281918%29.+Study+of+Engineering+Education Mann Report] noted an imminent lack of qualified engineers that could rapidly enter the workforce. There should be more hands-on experience, engineering educators should have practical work experience, and teaching should be more prominent even though research is also important. In 1955, the Grinter report specifically outlined undergraduate and graduate level engineering studies. Since then, some of these suggestions, including the senior capstone design course, have been implemented in public and private engineering institutions.
Engineering education policy is externally driven to some degree. [[ABET]] accreditation has incorporated industrial demands as part of the accreditation process. ABET EC 2000 emphasizes both technical (design, problem solving) and professional skills (teamwork, communication, ethical/global thinking).
''P-12 Educational Standards:''
National policies such as [[No Child Left Behind]] and [[Race to the Top]] have influenced the recruitment and retention of future engineers.
In April 2013, the Next Generation Science Standards were released as the science standards for K-12 science education in the [[United States]] to replace the [[National Science Education Standards]]. These include engineering-based standards embedded within the science standards. The National Assessment Governing Board has created a Technology and Literacy Framework for the 2014 National Assessment of Educational Progress. This will be a pilot test and may turn into a permanent fixture of future testing.
=== Educational ===
There is a disconnect between engineering education research findings and implementation of the findings into the classroom. Research findings are published in a variety of journals primarily read by other researchers, not P-12 teachers or university faculty outside of the Education field. This breakdown of transfer between research and practice prevents the desired outcomes at the heart of the research<ref>American Society for Engineering Education, 2009</ref><ref name="Borrego_Bernhard"/><ref name="Jesiek_etal_2010"/>
There have been proposals to connect Engineering Education practice and Engineering Education research. A cyclical model of transfer between research and practice has been proposed by Jesiek et al. (2010) and Borrego & Bernhard (2011). This model allows research and practice to continuously influence and develop one another.

'''Female copulatory vocalizations''', also called '''female copulation calls''' or '''coital vocalizations''', are produced by female [[primate]]s, including [[woman|human females]], and female non-primates. Copulatory vocalizations usually occur during [[sexual intercourse]] and are hence related to [[sexual activity]].<ref>{{cite book|last1=Thornhill|first1=R.|last2=Gangestad|first2=S. W.|title=The Evolutionary Biology of Human Female Sexuality|date=2008|publisher=Oxford University Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oIE8DwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=vocalizations%20OR%20%22copulation%20calls%22&f=false}}</ref> Vocalizations that occur before intercourse, for the purpose of attracting mates, are known as [[mating call]]s.
In [[primate]]s, copulation calling is typically observed at the end of [[mating]]<ref name="Pradhan et al. (2006)">{{cite journal|last1=Pradhan|first1=Gauri|last2=Engelhardt|first2=Antje|last3=van Schaik|first3=Carel|last4=Maestripieri|first4=Dario|title=The evolution of female copulation calls in primates: a review and a new model|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|date=January 2006|volume=59|issue=3|pages=333–343|doi=10.1007/s00265-005-0075-y}}</ref> and there are vast variations between species regarding its occurrence, frequency and form. It is agreed that coital vocalizations fulfill an [[evolution]]ary purpose<ref name="Dixson 2013">{{cite book|last1=Dixson|first1=A.|title=Primate Sexuality: Comparative Studies of the Prosimians, Monkeys, Apes, and Humans|date=2013|publisher=Oxford: UOP}}</ref> and that they serve as adaptive solutions to problems that the females face, such as [[infanticide]], as well as [[sperm competition|obtaining high quality sperm]].<ref name="Pradhan et al. (2006)"/>
In non-primates, copulatory calling predominantly occurs before copulation in order to attract mates ([[mating call]]). Calls vary in [[frequency]] (14 Hz<ref name=":0" /> to 70,000 Hz<ref name=":1" />) and function. One of the main purposes of females vocalizing is the induction of [[mate guarding]] behavior in males.<ref name=":2" /> Conversely, calls may also be used in order to attract high ranking mates who can prevent intercourse with the initial partner.<ref name=":3" /> This is done to incite [[sexual selection|male mate competition]].
In humans, coital vocalizations are linked to [[orgasm]],<ref name="Sex at Dawn">Christopher Ryan and Cacilda Jetha, ‘’[[Sex at Dawn|Sex at Dawn: How We Mate, Why We Stray, and What It Means for Modern Relationships]]’’ (Harper Perennial, 2011), pp. 255-57.</ref> hence occurring during [[sexual intercourse|copulation]] and serving as an expression of sexual pleasure. Vocalizations can be used intentionally by women in order to boost the self-esteem of their partner and to cause quicker [[ejaculation]].<ref name="GayleBrewer">{{cite journal | last1 = Brewer | first1 = Gayle | last2 = Hendrie | first2 = Colin A. | year = 2011 | title = Evidence to Suggest that Copulatory Vocalizations in Women Are Not a Reflexive Consequence of Orgasm | url = | journal = Archives of Sexual Behavior | volume = 40 | issue = 3| pages = 559–64 | pmid = 20480220 | doi=10.1007/s10508-010-9632-1}}</ref>
==In non-human primates==
===Occurrence, frequency and form===
[[File:Vocalization sonograms.jpg|thumb|Sonograms of female copulatory vocalizations of a human female (top), female baboon (middle), and female gibbon (bottom),<ref name="Hamilton_1406-07">{{cite journal | last1 = Hamilton | first1 = J. | last2 = Arrowood | first2 = P. C. | year = 1978 | title = Copulatory Vocalizations of Chacma Baboons (Papio Ursinus), gibbons (Hylobates Hoolock) and Humans | url = | journal = Science | volume = 200 | issue = 1405| pages = 1406–07 }}</ref> with time being plotted on the x-axis and the [[Audio frequency|pitch]] being represented on the y-axis.]]In non-human primates, copulatory vocalizations begin towards the end of the copulatory act or even after copulation.<ref name="Pradhan et al. (2006)"/> The percentage of vocalizations after copulation varies dependent on the non-human primate species studied. In long-tail macaques, for instance, 80% of copulations are followed by [[Sexual intercourse|copulation]] calls. In contrast, the percentage for [[chimpanzee]]s and [[Tonkean macaque]]s has been found to be 78.8% and 6%, respectively.<ref name="Maestripieri 106–113">{{Cite journal|title = Primate copulation calls and postcopulatory female choice|url = http://beheco.oxfordjournals.org/content/16/1/106|journal = Behavioral Ecology|date = 2005-01-01|issn = 1045-2249|pages = 106–113|volume = 16|issue = 1|doi = 10.1093/beheco/arh120|language = en|first = Dario|last = Maestripieri|first2 = James R.|last2 = Roney}}</ref> There is little consensus on what causes these inter-specific differences, given the lack of consistent findings within the literature.<ref name="Pradhan et al. (2006)"/> The typical quantity of specimen that are tested in [[experiment|experimental settings]] is often too low in order to allow any [[inference|general conclusions]] about the species as a whole.<ref name="Pradhan et al. (2006)"/> Another aspect of [[Sexual intercourse|coital]] vocalization that varies according to species is the form of the call: in [[macaque]]s and [[baboon]]s they manifest themselves as [[Guttural|grunts]], whereas other species such as [[talapoin]]s and [[chimpanzee]]s typically emit [[screaming]] sounds.<ref name="Pradhan et al. (2006)"/> The quality and structure of copulatory calls are analyzed by comparing their respective [[spectrogram]]s in terms of their frequency. Accordingly, some species produce calls that are structurally more complex than that of others. This is linked to the amount of [[Animal sexual behavior#Promiscuity|promiscuity]] exhibited, in a way that more promiscuous species emit more faceted calls in order to convey more information about themselves and hence render [[Signalling theory|self-advertisement]] more efficient.<ref name="Hamilton_1406-07"/>
===Adaptive function===
[[File:World 06 temp-1416046030-546725ce-620x348.jpg|thumb|A male Chacma baboon shows aggression towards a female and her offspring.]]Copulatory calls in primates serve an [[Adaptation|adaptive function]] and are [[sexual selection|sexually selected]].<ref name="Dixson 2013"/> Calling signals sexual receptivity of the female and therefore affects [[mate choice]]. There are many different hypotheses as to the exact adaptive function of female copulatory calls in primates and research on the subject is still in its early stages.<ref name="Pradhan et al. (2006)"/>
There is general agreement that copulatory calls are the adaptive solution to problems with [[reproductive success]]. In other words, copulatory vocalizations address issues that stand in the way of successfully producing [[offspring]] and guaranteeing its survival, such as the occurrence of infanticide.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Maestripieri|first1=Dario|title=Post-Copulatory Sexual Selection and Female Mating Vocalizations in Primates|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yhVRetJZrkM|accessdate=24 March 2016}}</ref> To prevent the killing of their offspring, female baboons employ copulatory calls in order to attract other males, allowing multiple mating acts and creating parental confusion among the males involved. The resulting uncertainty of who the father is hence reduces the occurrence of attacks, given the newly incited risk of potentially harming their own offspring.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Infanticide avoidance, sperm competition and mate choice: the function of copulation calls in female baboons|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347284712887|journal = Animal Behaviour|date = 1994-09-01|pages = 687–694|volume = 48|issue = 3|doi = 10.1006/anbe.1994.1288|first = Sanjida M.|last = O'Connell|first2 = Guy|last2 = Cowlishaw}}</ref> Additionally, mating in rapid successions also entails sperm competition, and therefore fulfills the additional function of obtaining high quality sperm.<ref name="stockley">{{cite journal |last1= Stockley |first1= P|year= 1997|title= Sexual conflict resulting from adaptations to sperm competition |volume= 12|pages= 154–159|journal= Trends Ecol. Evol.|doi=10.1016/S0169-5347(97)01000-8 |issue= 4 |pmid= 21238013}}</ref> This is especially important in species that do not openly advertise good genes via [[honest signal]]s.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Maestripieri|first1=Dario|last2=Roney|first2=James|title=Primate copulation calls and post-copulatory female choice|journal=Behavioral Ecology|date=2005|volume=16|pages=106–113|doi=10.1093/beheco/arh120}}</ref>
By attracting other males through post-copulatory calls, the female might provoke mate guarding behavior in their initial mate. This 'parental concentration',<ref name="Pradhan et al. (2006)"/> has two outcomes. Firstly, the male might be of high [[Fitness (biology)|quality]], allowing him to fend off those that were attracted by the call. In that case the female has not only gained someone who can protect her and who prevents infanticide through other males, but this also means that she was [[insemination|inseminated]] by a specimen with potentially good genes. Secondly, if the male fails to successfully guard her, she will mate with the newly arrived males, hence inciting sperm competition and paternity confusion (again preventing [[infanticide|attacks on her offspring]], as well as increasing her likelihood of obtaining high quality sperm). The calls produced by the female also carries information about the [[Dominance hierarchy|status]] of the male with whom she was copulating, thus allowing her to influence the likelihood of other males approaching.<ref name="Sex at Dawn"/>
Accordingly, copulatory calls serve more than a single adaptive function. There is no [[mutual exclusivity]] when it comes to addressing the two problems described, namely that of infanticide and receiving high quality sperm. However, by taking the female's [[menstrual cycle|cycle stage]] into account, sperm competition can be ruled out as the primary underlying cause of copulatory calling.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Townsend|first1=Simon|last2=Deschner|first2=T|last3=Zuberbühler|first3=K|title=Female chimpanzees use copulation calls flexibly to prevent social competition|journal=PLoS ONE|date=2008|volume=3 | issue = 6 |page=e2431|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0002431|pmid=22423311|pmc=3278306}}</ref> More precisely, females produce coital vocalizations also when they mate during non-fertile periods, which is therefore primarily aimed at attracting as many males as possible and to create parental confusion rather than obtaining high quality sperm.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lukas|first1=Dieter|last2=Huchard|first2=Elise|title=The evolution of infanticide by males in mammalian societies|journal=Science|date=2014|volume=346|issue=6211|pages=841–843|doi=10.1126/science.1257226|pmid=25395534}}</ref> Females have no interest in advertising their periods of [[fertility]], given that males would pick up on these patterns, reducing paternal confusion and causing an increase in [[infanticide|aggressive behavior towards her offspring]] from other males.<ref name="Pradhan et al. (2006)"/> Such hidden fertility has been coined [[concealed ovulation]], and is part of [[extended female sexuality]].
=== Alternative benefits ===
In addition to the incitement of parental confusion in order to avoid infanticide, female primates that exhibit [[promiscuity|promiscuous behavior]] also reap non-genetic material benefits. A female that uses vocalizations after copulating with her mate attracts other males, with whom she is also likely to engage in multiple acts of mating.<ref name="Hamilton_1406-07"/> As a consequence male mates provide non-genetic benefits, such as food, to the female they mated with.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rodrı́guez-Gironés|first1=M. A.|last2=Enquist|first2=M.|title=The evolution of female sexuality|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=2001|volume=61|issue=4|pages=695–704|doi=10.1006/anbe.2000.1630}}</ref> Such vocalization-facilitated promiscuity heightens the female's [[reproductive success]]. The strategy to mate with multiple partners in order to obtain material benefits can equally be observed in non-primates.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Stacey|first1=P. B.|title=Female promiscuity and male reproductive success in social birds and mammals.|journal=American Naturalist|date=1982|pages=51–64|doi=10.1086/283969}}</ref>
== In non-primates ==
=== Occurrence ===
In addition to emitting copulatory vocalizations during and after copulation (as it is mostly seen in primates), non-primate species also vocalize before engaging in mating. Vocalizations that are made prior to copulation are named [[mating call]]s. They serve as a means to advertise sexual receptivity and are predominantly used by males to attract female mates.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Fedorka|first1=K.|last2=Mousseau|first2=T.|title=Material and genetic benefits of female multiple mating and polyandry|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=2001|volume=64|issue=3|pages=361–367|doi=10.1006/anbe.2002.3052}}</ref> In general, non-primates emit more calls before copulating, as exemplified by the [[frog#call|croak]]s of male frogs<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Wilczynski | first1 = W. | last2 = McClelland | first2 = B. E. | last3 = Rand | first3 = A. S. | year = 1993 | title = Acoustic, auditory, and morphological divergence in three species of neotropical frog | url = | journal = Journal of Comparative Physiology A | volume = 172 | issue = 4| pages = 425–438 | doi=10.1007/bf00213524}}</ref> and the melodic tweeting of [[song sparrow]]s.<ref name=nemeth2012>{{cite journal|last=Nemeth|first=E|author2=Kempenaers, B |author3=Matessi, G |author4= Brumm, H |title=Rock sparrow song reflects male age and reproductive success|journal=PLoS ONE|year=2012|volume=7|issue=8|pages=e43259|pmid=22927955|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0043259 |pmc=3426517}}</ref>
=== Properties === [[File:Elephant Berlin Zoo having Sex cropped.JPG|thumb|Elephant copulation.]] In regard to the calling properties, frequency analysis is typically used in research to look at the complexity of the vocalization and to distinguish between calls, which is important in determining their function.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Gerhardt|first1=C.|title=Mating call recognition in the green treefrog (Hyla cinerea): importance of two frequency bands as a function of sound pressure level.|journal=Journal of Comparative Physiology A|date=1981|volume=144 | issue = 1 |pages=9–16|doi=10.1007/bf00612792}}</ref> Large frequency variations have been noted between species, ranging from 14 Hz to 70,000 Hz. [[Mice]], for instance, use 70,000 Hz calls continuously prior to copulation. They then lower the frequency down to 40,000 Hz during the copulatory act, therefore two qualitatively different calls are used for attracting mates as compared to the actual act of mating.<ref name=":1">{{cite journal | last1 = White | first1 = N. R. | last2 = Prasad | first2 = M. | last3 = Barfield | first3 = R. J. | last4 = Nyby | first4 = J. G. | year = 1998 | title = 40-and 70-kHz vocalizations of mice (Mus musculus) during copulation | url = | journal = Physiology & Behavior | volume = 63 | issue = 4| pages = 467–473 | doi=10.1016/s0031-9384(97)00484-8}}</ref> Most of the calling in mice is done by males. They use these [[ultrasound|ultrasonic]] calls (> 20,000 Hz and hence not discernible by the human ear) to attract females, with the quantity of calls being related to the male's mating success, making these vocalizations a [[sexual selection|sexually selected]] trait.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Pomerantz | first1 = S. M. | last2 = Nunez | first2 = A. A. | last3 = Bean | first3 = N. J. | year = 1983 | title = Female behavior is affected by male ultrasonic vocalizations in house mice | url = | journal = Physiology & Behavior | volume = 31 | issue = 1| pages = 91–96 | doi=10.1016/0031-9384(83)90101-4}}</ref>
On the other end of the spectrum, female [[African elephant]]s use very low frequency calls of 14–35 Hz prior to, as well as during, copulation.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal | last1 = Poole | first1 = J. H. | last2 = Payne | first2 = K. | last3 = Langbauer Jr | first3 = W. R. | last4 = Moss | first4 = C. J. | year = 1988 | title = The social contexts of some very low frequency calls of African elephants | url = | journal = Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology | volume = 22 | issue = 6| pages = 385–392 | doi=10.1007/bf00294975}}</ref> Due to their low frequency these calls can be heard for several kilometers and are therefore effective in signalling receptivity. The vocalizations of female elephants are also used in order to incite [[mate guarding]] behavior in the male,<ref name=":2">{{cite journal|last1=Poole|first1=J.|title=Mate guarding, reproductive success and female choice in African elephants|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=1989|volume=37|pages=842–849|doi=10.1016/0003-3472(89)90068-7}}</ref> which manifests itself in the form of fighting off any newly arriving mates. Not only females make use of this, as male [[Columbian ground squirrel]]s have been observed to use copulatory vocalizations in order to announce their post-copulatory mate guarding to others.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Manno | first1 = T. G. | last2 = Nesterova | first2 = A. P. | last3 = Debarbieri | first3 = L. M. | last4 = Kennedy | first4 = S. E. | last5 = Wright | first5 = K. S. | last6 = Dobson | first6 = F. S. | year = 2007 | title = Why do male columbian ground squirrels give a mating call? | url = | journal = Animal Behaviour | volume = 74 | issue = 5| pages = 1319–1327 | doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2007.02.033}}</ref> In addition to being used to retain the mate via mate guarding induction, female copulatory vocalizations can also be employed to achieve his departure. [[Red junglefowl]]s, for instance, utilize calls in order to prevent or end unwanted copulations by attracting another high-ranking male fowl.<ref name=":3">{{cite journal | last1 = Løvlie | first1 = H. | last2 = Zidar | first2 = J. | last3 = Berneheim | first3 = C. | year = 2014 | title = A cry for help: Female distress calling during copulation is context dependent | url = | journal = Animal Behaviour | volume = 92 | issue = | pages = 151–157 | doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2014.04.002}}</ref> Further effects of female calling on male's behavior are illustrated by [[spider]]s that have been shown to [[Stridulation|stridulate]] before copulation to inform males of sexual receptivity<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Dutto | first1 = M. S. | last2 = Calbacho-Rosa | first2 = L. | last3 = Peretti | first3 = A. V. | year = 2011 | title = Signalling and sexual conflict: Female spiders use stridulation to inform males of sexual receptivity | url = | journal = Ethology | volume = 117 | issue = 11| pages = 1040–1049 | doi=10.1111/j.1439-0310.2011.01957.x}}</ref> as well as during intercourse in order to influence male genitalic movements.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Peretti | first1 = A. | last2 = Eberhard | first2 = W. G. | last3 = Briceño | first3 = R. D. | year = 2006 | title = Copulatory dialogue: Female spiders sing during copulation to influence male genitalic movements | doi = 10.1016/j.anbehav.2006.01.014| journal = Animal Behaviour | volume = 72 | issue = 2| pages = 413–421 }}</ref>
Moreover, attracting new mates by calling out during copulation can entail many benefits for the female. Female [[cricket (insect)|cricket]]s which mate with multiple partners receive a greater number of [[nuptial gift]]s,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tregenza|first1=T.|last2=Wedell|first2=N.|title=Benefits of Multiple Mates in the Cricket Gryllus bimaculatus|journal=Evolution|date=1998|volume=52|issue=6|pages=1726–1730|doi=10.2307/2411345|jstor=2411345}}</ref> causing them to lay a larger quantity of eggs, hence increasing their [[reproductive success]].
==In humans==
Theories are more diverse in regard to women’s sexual vocalizing. On the one hand, researchers have noted some apparently communicative patterns in women’s copulatory vocalizations that suggest some parallels with those of other primates (including an invitation to sperm competition, given that female sexual vocalizations, like those of other primates, serve as "copulation calls" noticeable to other men and exciting to them if overheard<ref name="Sex at Dawn"/>). One study, for instance, has noted that female sexual vocalizations tend to become more intense as she approaches orgasm; at orgasm her vocalization tends to become very rapid, with a regular rhythm that includes equal note lengths and intervals between notes, which male vocalization typically lacks.<ref name="Hamilton_1406-07" /> This is especially frequent when her orgasm occurs during penile-vaginal intercourse.<ref name="GayleBrewer" /> By exciting her partner with her vocalizations and bringing about his orgasm at that point, she helps ensure that the [[semen|seminal pool]] is available for her [[cervix]] to dip into as her [[vagina]] relaxes after her orgasm.<ref name="Hamilton_1406-07"/> Copulatory vocalizations may also be a type of mate retention behaviour. One study found that women who perceived a high risk of [[infidelity]] in their relationship were more likely to utilize copulatory vocalizations in order to [[Fake orgasm|fake an orgasm]], along with other mate retention behaviours.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kaighobadi|first=Farnaz|last2=Shackelford|first2=Todd K.|last3=Weekes-Shackelford|first3=Viviana A.|date=2011-11-17|title=Do Women Pretend Orgasm to Retain a Mate?|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10508-011-9874-6|journal=Archives of Sexual Behavior|language=en|volume=41|issue=5|pages=1121–1125|doi=10.1007/s10508-011-9874-6|issn=0004-0002|pmc=3563256|pmid=22089325}}</ref>
On the other hand, recent studies have indicated that most copulatory vocalizations in women do not accompany their own orgasm, but rather their partner’s ejaculation. The study showed that the man typically finds the woman’s vocalization arousing and highly exciting, and that the woman herself is aware of this. Most women in the study, furthermore, indicated that they vocalized during intercourse to make their man ejaculate more quickly, or to boost his enjoyment or [[self-esteem]], or both.<ref name="GayleBrewer"/> A correlation has been found between the frequency of vocalizations and sexual satisfaction for both men and women.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Babin | first1 = E. A. | year = 2013 | title = An examination of predictors of nonverbal and verbal communication of pleasure during sex and sexual satisfaction | url = | journal = Journal of Social and Personal Relationships | volume = 30 | issue = 3| pages = 270–292 | doi=10.1177/0265407512454523}}</ref>
The reasons that women gave for wanting to force a quick ejaculation include the alleviation of the female's pain, fatigue, or even boredom, or simply to stay within some imposed time restriction for sexual activity. Reasons for wanting to boost the male self-esteem included reinforcing the [[pair bond]] that intercourse helps to strengthen, and thus reducing emotional and sexual infidelity and abandonment.<ref name="GayleBrewer" /> The researchers note that all of these goals are apparently congruent with female copulatory vocalizations in non-human primates.
It is also possible that some vocalizations are due to [[hyperventilation]]. Both men and women can experience hyperventilation during sexual arousal,<ref>Masters W. H., Johnson V. E. Human Sexual Response. Boston: Little Brown and Co, 1966.</ref> which can involve involuntary vocalizations.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Passie | first1 = T. | last2 = Hartman | first2 = U. | last3 = Schneider | first3 = U. | last4 = Emrich | first4 = H.M. | year = 2003 | title = On the function of groaning and hyperventilation during sexual intercourse: Intensification of sexual experience by altering brain metabolism through hypercapnia | url = | journal = Medical Hypotheses | volume = 60 | issue = 5| pages = 660–663 | doi=10.1016/s0306-9877(03)00010-0}}</ref>
